content: The Act may be cited as the "Chemical Security Act of 1999". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Chemical Security Act of 1999", defines key terms such as Administrator, Off-site Consequence Analysis Submission, covered stationary source, and official use. The term "authorized contractor" refers to a person responsible for managing risk management plans under the Clean Air Act, contracted by the Administrator, the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, a State, or a local agency. SEC. 3. ONE-YEAR MORATORIUM FOR CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION. Prohibition on disclosure of Off-site Consequence Analysis Submission for Congressional consideration and reports under the Clean Air Act. Applies for one year after a moratorium for Congressional consideration. The prohibition on disclosing Off-site Consequence Analysis Submission under the Clean Air Act applies for one year after the enactment of the Act. The violation of this prohibition is punishable as an infraction under the United States Code. After June 21, 1999, the Administrator will release risk management plan information to the public without facility identification. Penalties for violations of subsection (a) cannot exceed $100,000 for a single person or organization. Emergency planning meetings must be conducted by covered stationary sources within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each owner or operator of a covered stationary source must hold a meeting with community representatives, employees, contractors, and emergency responders to discuss security measures against attacks. A certification must be sent to the FBI Director within 10 months of the Act's enactment confirming the meeting took place. SEC. 4. SITE SECURITY STUDY AND REPORTS TO CONGRESS. The Attorney General will review the vulnerability of covered stationary sources to criminal and terrorist activity, industry practices, transportation security, and effectiveness of the Act. A report with recommendations for enhancing security and the need for additional legislation will be submitted to Congress six months after the Act's enactment. The Attorney General will submit biennial updates on information security measures ensuring access to risk management information without geographical restrictions. The Comptroller General will report on health and environmental effects of public disclosure of information, consulting with various stakeholders and examining reductions in toxic chemical releases. The curr_chunk discusses releases related to reporting requirements under section 313 of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (Toxics Release Inventory). SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
